trans-unit.source: Migration using Visual Studio and SSDT
trans-unit.target: Migration using Visual Studio and SSDT

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure SQL Database, database migration, import database, export database, migration wizard
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure SQL Database, database migration, import database, export database, migration wizard

trans-unit.source: Update database in place then deploy to Azure SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Update database in place then deploy to Azure SQL Database

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: Use this Option when the migration of an on-premises database to Azure SQL Database V12 requires schema changes because the database uses SQL Server features that are not supported in Azure SQL Database, or to test whether non-supported features are present within an on-premises database.
trans-unit.target: Use this Option when the migration of an on-premises database to Azure SQL Database V12 requires schema changes because the database uses SQL Server features that are not supported in Azure SQL Database, or to test whether non-supported features are present within an on-premises database.

trans-unit.source: Use the [lastest SQL Server Data Tools for Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt204009.aspx) with Visual Studio 2013 Update 4 or later.
trans-unit.target: Use the [lastest SQL Server Data Tools for Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt204009.aspx) with Visual Studio 2013 Update 4 or later.

trans-unit.source: With this option:
trans-unit.target: With this option:

trans-unit.source: SQL Server Data Tools for Visual Studio ("SSDT") is first used to create a database project from the source database.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server Data Tools for Visual Studio ("SSDT") is first used to create a database project from the source database.

trans-unit.source: The project’s target platform is then set to Azure SQL Database V12 and the project is built to identify all compatibility issues.
trans-unit.target: The project’s target platform is then set to Azure SQL Database V12 and the project is built to identify all compatibility issues.

trans-unit.source: Once the project builds successfully, the schema is published back to a copy of the source database (do not overwrite the source database).
trans-unit.target: Once the project builds successfully, the schema is published back to a copy of the source database (do not overwrite the source database).

trans-unit.source: The data compare feature in SSDT is then used to compare the source database to the newly created Azure SQL compatible database and then update the new database with data from the source database.
trans-unit.target: The data compare feature in SSDT is then used to compare the source database to the newly created Azure SQL compatible database and then update the new database with data from the source database.

trans-unit.source: The updated database is then deployed to Azure using SSMS, either directly or by exporting and then importing a BACPAC file.
trans-unit.target: The updated database is then deployed to Azure using SSMS, either directly or by exporting and then importing a BACPAC file.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Note: If a schema-only deployment is required, the updated schema can be published directly from Visual Studio to Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Note: If a schema-only deployment is required, the updated schema can be published directly from Visual Studio to Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Migration Steps
trans-unit.target: Migration Steps

trans-unit.source: Open the **SQL Server Object Explorer** in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Open the **SQL Server Object Explorer** in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Use **Add SQL Server** to connect to the SQL Server instance containing the database being migrated.
trans-unit.target: Use **Add SQL Server** to connect to the SQL Server instance containing the database being migrated.

trans-unit.source: Locate the database in the explorer, right click it and select **Create New Project…**
trans-unit.target: Locate the database in the explorer, right click it and select **Create New Project…**

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: Configure the import settings to **Import application-scoped objects only**.
trans-unit.target: Configure the import settings to **Import application-scoped objects only**.

trans-unit.source: Uncheck the options to import the following: referenced logins, permissions and database settings.
trans-unit.target: Uncheck the options to import the following: referenced logins, permissions and database settings.

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: Click **Start** to import the database and create the project, which will contain a T-SQL script file for each object in the database.
trans-unit.target: Click **Start** to import the database and create the project, which will contain a T-SQL script file for each object in the database.

trans-unit.source: The script files are nested in folders within the project.
trans-unit.target: The script files are nested in folders within the project.

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio Solution Explorer, right click on the database project and select Properties.
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio Solution Explorer, right click on the database project and select Properties.

trans-unit.source: This will open the **Project Settings** page on which you should configure the Target Platform to Microsoft Azure SQL Database V12.
trans-unit.target: This will open the **Project Settings** page on which you should configure the Target Platform to Microsoft Azure SQL Database V12.

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the project and select **Build** to build the project.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the project and select **Build** to build the project.

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: The **Error List** displays each incompatibility.
trans-unit.target: The **Error List** displays each incompatibility.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the user name NT AUTHORITY\NETWORK SERVICE is incompatible.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the user name NT AUTHORITY\NETWORK SERVICE is incompatible.

trans-unit.source: Since it is incompatible, you can comment it out or remove it (and address the implications of removing this login and role from the database solution).
trans-unit.target: Since it is incompatible, you can comment it out or remove it (and address the implications of removing this login and role from the database solution).

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: Double-click the first script to open the script in a query window and comment out the script, and then execute the script.
trans-unit.target: Double-click the first script to open the script in a query window and comment out the script, and then execute the script.

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: Repeat this process for each script containing incompatibilities until no error remain.
trans-unit.target: Repeat this process for each script containing incompatibilities until no error remain.

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: When the database is free of errors right click on the project and select **Publish** to build and publish the database to a copy of the source database (it is highly recommended to use a copy, at least initially).
trans-unit.target: When the database is free of errors right click on the project and select **Publish** to build and publish the database to a copy of the source database (it is highly recommended to use a copy, at least initially).

trans-unit.source: Before you publish, depending on the source SQL Server version (earlier than SQL Server 2014), you may need to reset the project’s target platform to enable deployment.
trans-unit.target: Before you publish, depending on the source SQL Server version (earlier than SQL Server 2014), you may need to reset the project’s target platform to enable deployment.

trans-unit.source: If you are migrating an older SQL Server database you must not introduce any features into the project that are not supported in the source SQL Server unless you first migrate the database to a newer version of SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: If you are migrating an older SQL Server database you must not introduce any features into the project that are not supported in the source SQL Server unless you first migrate the database to a newer version of SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: In SQL Server Object Explorer, right-click your source database and click **Data Comparison** to compare the project to the original database to understand what changes have been made by the wizard.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Server Object Explorer, right-click your source database and click **Data Comparison** to compare the project to the original database to understand what changes have been made by the wizard.

trans-unit.source: Select your Azure SQL V12 version of the database and then click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Select your Azure SQL V12 version of the database and then click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: Review the differences detected and then click **Update Target** to migrate data from the source database into the Azure SQL V12 database.
trans-unit.target: Review the differences detected and then click **Update Target** to migrate data from the source database into the Azure SQL V12 database.

trans-unit.source: alt text
trans-unit.target: alt text

trans-unit.source: Deploy the Azure SQL V12 compatible database schema and data to Azure SQL Database using SSMS.
trans-unit.target: Deploy the Azure SQL V12 compatible database schema and data to Azure SQL Database using SSMS.

trans-unit.source: See [Migrating a compatible database using SSMS.](sql-database-migrate-ssms.md)
trans-unit.target: See [Migrating a compatible database using SSMS.](sql-database-migrate-ssms.md)
